title: Ticket #883: VM universe refactor
description:
The following are open items for refactoring in the next series:

What:

Coding: (In general all the code is subject to review.) 

1.) Nix VMPARAM_ and JobVM from classad attributes
2.) Cleanup xentype.h & .cpp it's rather difficult to follow
3.) move vmware to libvirt, and any other new vm (virtbox)
4.) support for libvirt on windows?

Submission changes: 

1.) Consider having user provide libvirt xml description file for VMs that
work with libvirt. Then remove array of submit params specific to
xen/kvm/vmware et al. Call it vm_description_file or vm_config_file.

2.) Have Condor parse libvirt and vmware description files to get list of
files to be transfered. Then kill xen_transfer_files params and simply say transefer_file = yes || no.

3.) Maybe get rid of vm_should_transfer_files. Allow VM files to be visible
at execute machine but not submit machine. Support file transfer hooks
for vm files.

4.) Investigate usefulness of execute-machine provided kernel/initrd/etc.
Can we just require them to be included with user-provided image?

Param changes: 

1.) Consolidation can occur across the params.

2.) VM_GAHP_SERVER should be set to default value in config file (not
commented out).

3.) VMWARE_LOCAL_SETTINGS_FILE and XEN_LOCAL_SETTINGS_FILE can be replaced
with VM_LOCAL_SETTINGS_FILE or just removed. Are these params useful?

Open bugs/items which need to be addressed: 

1.) libvirtd restarting causes vm-gahp to continue on even though the connection to the vm is gone.
2.) All existing vm-universe bugs
    #45,#272,#302,#303,#387,#405,#515,#517,#523,#618,#625,#626,#740,#854,#858
3.) test and verify xen_type = vmx..?
4.) remove VM_SCRIPT && XEN_SCRIPT entirely?
5.) Update notes on VM_BRDIGE_SCRIPT for KVM
6.) remove mkisofs, let the xml specify the files, and handle

Why: 

As we have seen with the 7.4 release, there are a fair number of issues with
the vm-universe and it is my goal to ensure that the vm-universe is flexible,
simple, reliable, and *testable*.

How:

I would like to team up with someone from UW (Jamie) and run through the following: 

1.) Evaluation of current operation and use cases.
2.) Define updated use case senario, and open to a broader audience (market feedback)
3.) Evaluate current implementation and determine what we would like to do to meet the updated use case senario
4.) Define attack plan, and test plan
5.) Switch off between writing tests and attack plan.
6.) goto 1 and verify.

Expected Output: 

1.) Documentation (detail is subject to debate)
2.) Test Plan (To avoid the mistakes of the 7.4 release)
3.) Updated vm-gahp

2010-Dec-06 19:41:47 by bbockelm:
Sorry, forgot another two issues:

  • condor_submit messes up the determination of file transfers, and fails at sites without a shared file system unless you specify the (undocumented) magic string "REQUIREMENTS = TARGET.FileSystemDomain ! FALSE"
  • The RHEL5 libvirt creates a log file per unique VM name created. Condor gives each VM a unique name, meaning there's one log file per VM universe job in /var/log/libvirt/qemu. These files don't get cleaned up ever (but they do appear to get logrotated). We probably should consider naming the VM after the slot rather than the job.

2010-Dec-20 10:28:06 by bbockelm:
If we're going to dig into the VM-GAHP code, I do have one feature request:

VM Universe should be able to create and mount a scratch partition inside the VM. This would allow us to keep the size of our VMs down to a minimum - right now, the VMs tend toward 10GB+ because CMS requires 10GB of scratch space. This causes us to add the extra step of compressing the (mostly sparse) image when transferring it.

Thoughts? My understanding of libvirt is this wouldn't be overly difficult.

2011-Feb-08 12:00:00 by tiradani:
Here is one use case for Brian's request. Presumably, a worker node would have plenty of disk space available for jobs. In EC2, you have your disk image where your OS resides. Also, automatically mounted is temporary disk space that is available during the VM run time only. In essence, what I would like is to have the ability to tell Condor to mount a worker node directory in the VM as scratch space. Once the VM is done running, wipe out the directory so that all cruft is cleaned up. This will enable me to create VMs that are small in file size and easier to distribute. From a site perspective, getting the smaller images to the worker nodes is easier than trying to stage out 10GB+ VMs (even if you pre-stage, that is a lot of wasted disk space once you factor in multiple users and multiple versions).
